musicalLanguage.description: Duke Ellington's sophisticated swing masterpiece, co-written with Billy Strayhorn. The tune is built on a series of ii-V pairs that shift chromatically — Dm7-G7, then Em7-A7 — creating an elegant, serpentine harmonic motion. The melody is angular and hip, full of chromatic neighbor tones.
musicalLanguage.structure: AABA — 32 bars. This excerpt: first A section (8 bars)
keyMoments: Bar 1-2: Dm7 to G7 — first ii-V pair targeting C
Bar 3-4: Em7 to A7 — second ii-V pair targeting D. The chromatic shift is the magic.
Bar 5-8: Resolution and turnaround — the phrase lands and resets
teachingGoals: Chromatic ii-V pairs — the backbone of Ellington harmony
Swing rhythm — crisp, bouncy, big-band feel
Chromatic approach notes in the melody
styleTips: Play with swing confidence — this is Ellington, not a ballad
Short, punchy articulation on the melody — staccato where marked
Left hand comps in a relaxed swing pattern, slightly behind the beat

measures.teachingNote: Dm7 — the melody uses a chromatic enclosure around E. Swing the eighths!
G7 — same melodic figure repeated. The ii-V pair is a matching set.
Em7 — the whole pattern shifts up a step. Same shape, new key center.
A7 — second ii-V completes. Notice how the bass moves chromatically: D-G, E-A.
AbMaj7 passing chord — a surprise! The melody descends smoothly.
DbMaj7 to C — chromatic resolution. The left hand walks down.

measures.leftHand: D3:q F3 A3:q G2:q B2 F3:q
measures.teachingNote: Dm7-G7 returns for the turnaround. The A section is about to repeat.
CMaj7 — resolution. Clean and satisfying. The form resets.
